'''Enzyme replacement therapy''' ('''ERT''') is a medical treatment which replaces an [[enzyme]] that is deficient or absent in the body.<ref name="auto6">{{Cite journal|pmid=28314976|year=2017|author1=Ries|first1=M|title=Enzyme replacement therapy and beyond-in memoriam Roscoe O. Brady, M.D. (1923–2016)|journal=Journal of Inherited Metabolic Disease|volume=40|issue=3|pages=343–356|doi=10.1007/s10545-017-0032-8}}</ref> Usually, this is done by giving the patient an [[Intravenous therapy|intravenous (IV) infusion]] of a solution containing the enzyme.<ref name="auto6" />
ERT is currently available for some lysosomal storage diseases: [[Gaucher's disease|Gaucher disease]], [[Fabry disease]], [[Mucopolysaccharidosis|MPS I]], [[Hunter syndrome|MPS II (Hunter syndrome)]], [[Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome|MPS VI]] and [[Pompe disease]].<ref name="auto6" /> ERT does not correct the underlying genetic defect, but it increases the concentration of the enzyme that the patient is lacking.<ref name="auto6" /> ERT has also been used to treat patients with [[severe combined immunodeficiency]] (SCID) resulting from an adenosine deaminase deficiency ([[Adenosine deaminase deficiency|ADA-SCID]]).<ref name="auto">{{Cite journal|pmid=17300989|year=2007|author1=Booth|first1=C|title=Management options for adenosine deaminase deficiency; proceedings of the EBMT satellite workshop (Hamburg, March 2006)|journal=Clinical Immunology|volume=123|issue=2|pages=139–47|last2=Hershfield|first2=M|last3=Notarangelo|first3=L|last4=Buckley|first4=R|last5=Hoenig|first5=M|last6=Mahlaoui|first6=N|last7=Cavazzana-Calvo|first7=M|last8=Aiuti|first8=A|last9=Gaspar|first9=H. B.|doi=10.1016/j.clim.2006.12.009}}</ref>
Other treatment options for patients with enzyme or protein deficiencies include [[substrate reduction therapy]], [[gene therapy]], and [[Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation|bone-marrow derived stem cell transplantation.<ref name="auto6" />]]
== History ==
ERT was developed in 1964 by Christian de Duve and Roscoe Brady.<ref name="auto6" /><ref>{{Cite book|last1=Neufeld|first1= E. F. |date=2006|chapter=Chapter 10: Enzyme replacement therapy – a brief history|veditors= Mehta A, Beck M, Sunder-Plassmann G|title= Fabry Disease: Perspectives from 5 Years of FOS|location= Oxford|publisher= Oxford PharmaGenesis|isbn= 978-1-903539-03-3|pmid= 21290685}}</ref> Leading work was done on this subject at the Department of Physiology at the University of Alberta by Mark J. Poznansky and Damyanti Bhardwaj, where a model for enzyme therapy was developed using rats.<ref>{{Cite journal|doi=10.1007/BF02783734|pmid= 6395807|year= 1984|author1= Poznansky|first1= M. J.|title= Enzyme-albumin polymers. New approaches to the use of enzymes in medicine|journal= Applied biochemistry and biotechnology|volume= 10|pages= 41–56}}</ref> ERT was not used in clinical practice until 1991, after the FDA gave [[orphan drug]] approval for the treatment of Gaucher disease with [[Alglucerase]].<ref name="auto6" /> ERTs were initially manufactured by isolating the therapeutic enzyme from human placenta.<ref name="auto6" /> The FDA has now approved ERTs that are derived from other human cells, animal cells (i.e. Chinese hamster ovary cells, or CHO cells), and plant cells.<ref name="auto6" />
== Medical uses == [[Lysosomal storage disease]]s are fatal group of diseases and a main application of ERT. [[Lysosome]]s are cellular organelles that are responsible for the metabolism of many different macromolecules and proteins.<ref name="auto1">{{Cite journal|pages=111–113|doi=10.4161/cib.20373|pmc=3376041|year=2012|author1=Weiss|first1=N|title=Cross-talk between TRPML1 channel, lipids and lysosomal storage diseases|journal=Communicative & Integrative Biology|volume=5|issue=2|pmid=22808310}}</ref> They use enzymes to break down macromolecules, which are recycled or disposed.<ref name="auto1" /> As of 2012, there are 50 lysosomal storage diseases, and more are still being discovered.<ref name="auto2">"Lysosomal Storage Disorders – NORD (National Organization For Rare Disorders)". ''NORD (National Organization for Rare Disorders)''. Apr. 2017, from https://rarediseases.org/rare-diseases/lysosomal-storage-disorders/.</ref><ref name="auto1" /> These disorders arise because of genetic mutations that prevent the production of certain enzymes used in the lysosomes.<ref name="auto1" /> The missing enzyme often leads to a build-up of the [[Substrate (biochemistry)|substrate]] within the body. This can result in a variety of symptoms, many of which are severe and can affect the skeleton, brain, skin, heart, and the central nervous system.<ref name="auto2" /> Increasing the concentration of the missing enzyme within the body has been shown to improve the body's normal cellular metabolic processes and reduce substrate concentration in the body.<ref name="auto" />
ERT has also been successful in treating severe combined immunodeficiency caused by an adenosine deaminase deficiency (ADA-SCID).<ref name="auto3">{{Cite journal|pmid=26684479|year=2016|author1=Tartibi|first1=H. M.|title=A 24-Year Enzyme Replacement Therapy in an Adenosine-deaminase-Deficient Patient|journal=Pediatrics|volume=137|issue=1|pages=e20152169|last2=Hershfield|first2=M. S.|last3=Bahna|first3=S. L.|doi=10.1542/peds.2015-2169}}</ref> This is a fatal childhood disease that requires early medical intervention.<ref name="auto3" /> When the enzyme adenosine deaminase is deficient in the body, the result is a toxic build-up of metabolites that impair [[lymphocyte]] development and function.<ref name="auto3" /> Many ADA deficient children with SCID have been treated with the polyethylene glycol-conjugated adenosine deaminase (PEG-ADA) enzyme. This is a form of ERT that has resulted in healthier, longer lives for patients with ADA-SCID.<ref name="auto3" /> {| class="wikitable" |+Nine lysosomal storage diseases and corresponding enzyme therapies. Information in this table is from [[Pivotal trial|pivotal clinical trials]].<ref name="auto6" /> |- ! Disease !! Enzyme !! Administration and Dosage in Pivotal Clinical Trials |- | Fabry disease || Agalsidase beta || IV ''Age range 16–61'': 1 mg/kg every 2 weeks |- | Fabry disease || Agalsidase alfa* || IV ''Adult males'': 0.2 mg/kg every 2 weeks |- | Gaucher disease || Imiglucerase || IV ''Age range 12–69'': 15–60 U/kg every 2 weeks |- | Gaucher disease || Taliglucerase alfa || IV ''Age range 19–74'': 11–73 U/kg every 2 weeks |- | Gaucher disease || Velaglucerase alfa || IV ''Age range 4–62'': 15–60 U/kg every 2 weeks |- | Gaucher disease type I || Alglucerase || IV ''Age range 7–42'': 2.5 U/kg 3 times a week, up to 60 U/kg as frequently as once a week or as infrequently as every 4 weeks |- | Lysosomal acid lipase deficiency (Wolman disease/CESD) || Sebelipase alpha || IV ''Age range 1–6 months'': 1 mg/kg every 2 weeks
''Age range 4–58'': 1–3 mg/kg weekly |- | MPS I || Laronidase || IV ''Age range 6–43'': 100 U/kg weekly |- | MPS II || Idursulfase || IV ''Age range 5–31'': 0.5 mg/kg weekly |- | MPS IVA || Elosulfase alpha || IV ''Age range 5–57'': 2 mg/kg weekly |- | MPS VI || Galsulfase || IV ''Age range 5–29'': 1 mg/kg weekly |- | Pompe disease || Alglucosidase alpha (160L bioreactor) || IV ''Age range 1–3.5'': 20 mg/kg every 2 weeks |- | Pompe disease || Alglucosidase alpha (4000L bioreactor) || IV ''Age range 10–70'': 20 mg/kg every 2 weeks |}
== Administration == ERT is administered by IV infusion.<ref name="auto6" /><ref name="auto3" /><ref name="auto7">{{cite journal|pmid=27384562|pmc=4964441|year=2016|author1=Coutinho|first1=M. F.|title=Less is More: Substrate Reduction Therapy for Lysosomal Storage Disorders|journal=International Journal of Molecular Sciences|volume=17|issue=7|pages=1065|last2=Santos|first2=J. I.|last3=Alves|first3=S|doi=10.3390/ijms17071065}}</ref> Typically, infusions occur every week or every two weeks.<ref name="auto6" /> For some types of ERT, these infusions can occur as infrequently as every four weeks.<ref name="auto6" />
== Complications == ERT is not a cure for lysosomal storage diseases, and it requires lifelong IV infusions of the therapeutic enzyme.<ref name="auto7" /> This procedure is expensive; in the United States, it may cost over $200,000 annually.<ref name="auto7" /> The distribution of the therapeutic enzyme in the body ([[biodistribution]]) after these IV infusions is not uniform.<ref name="auto7" /> The enzyme in less available to certain areas in the body, like the bones, lungs, brain. For this reason, many symptoms of lysosomal storage diseases remain untreated by ERT, especially neurological symptoms.<ref name="auto7" /> Additionally, the efficacy of ERT is often reduced due to an unwanted immune response against the enzyme, which prevents metabolic function.<ref name="auto7" />
== Other treatments for enzyme deficiencies == Substrate reduction therapy is another method for treating lysosomal storage diseases.<ref name="auto7" /> In this treatment, the accumulated compounds are inhibited from forming in the body of a patient suffering from a lysosomal storage disease.<ref name="auto7" /> The accumulated compounds are responsible for the symptoms of these disorders, and they form via a multi-step biological pathway.<ref name="auto7" /> Substrate reduction therapy uses a small molecule to interrupt this multi-step pathway and inhibit the biosynthesis of these compounds.<ref name="auto7" /> This type of treatment is taken orally.<ref name="auto7" /> It does not induce an unwanted immune response, and a single type of small molecule could be used to treat many lysosomal storage diseases.<ref name="auto7" /> Substrate reduction therapy is FDA approved and there is at least one treatment available on the market.<ref name="auto7" />
Gene therapy aims to replace a missing protein in the body through the use of [[Vectors in gene therapy|vectors]], usually [[viral vector]]s.<ref name="auto4">"How does gene therapy work? - Genetics Home Reference." U.S. National Library of Medicine. April 18, 2017, from https://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/primer/therapy/procedures.</ref> In gene therapy, a gene encoding for a certain protein is inserted into a vector.<ref name="auto4" /> The vector containing the therapeutic gene is then injected into the patient.<ref name="auto4" /> Once inside the body the vector introduces the therapeutic gene into host cells, and the protein encoded by the newly inserted gene is then produced by the body's own cells.<ref name="auto4" /> This type of therapy can correct for the missing protein/enzyme in patients with lysosomal storage diseases.<ref name="auto6" />
Hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplantation is another treatment for lysosomal storage diseases.<ref name="auto8" /> HSCs are derived from bone-marrow.<ref name="auto5">Domen, J., Wagers, A., & Weissman, I. "Bone Marrow (Hematopoietic) Stem Cells." April 19, 2017, from https://stemcells.nih.gov/info/Regenerative_Medicine/2006chapter2.htm.</ref> These cells have the ability to mature into the many cell types that comprise blood, including red blood cells, platelets, and white blood cells.<ref name="auto5" /> Patients suffering from enzyme deficiencies often undergo HSC transplantations in which HSCs from a healthy donor are injected. This treatment introduces HSCs that regularly produce the deficient enzyme since they have normal metabolic function.<ref name="auto8">{{cite journal|pmid=26604151|year=2016|author1=Biffi|first1=A|title=Gene therapy for lysosomal storage disorders: A good start|journal=Human Molecular Genetics|volume=25|issue=R1|pages=R65–75|doi=10.1093/hmg/ddv457}}</ref> This treatment is often used to treat the central nervous system of patients with some lysosomal storage diseases.<ref name="auto8" />

The '''Expedited Funds Availability Act''' (EFA or EFAA) was enacted in 1987 by the [[United States Congress]] for the purpose of standardizing hold periods on deposits made to [[commercial bank]]s and to regulate institutions' use of deposit holds. It is also referred to as '''Regulation CC''' or '''Reg CC''', after the [[Federal Reserve]] regulation that implements the act. The law is codified in Title 12, Chapter 41 of the [[United States Code|US Code]] and Title 12, Part 229 of the [[Code of Federal Regulations]]{{ref|1}}.
== Disclosure == Financial institutions must disclose their hold policies to all account holders, and make the policy available in written form upon request by any customer. It must also be provided at the time of opening of all new accounts.
Additional disclosures are required on deposit slips, at [[automated teller machine]]s, and when the policy is changed in any way.
== Types of hold == Regulation CC stipulates four types of holds that a bank may place on a [[Cheque|check deposit]] at its discretion. Each has its own qualifications and it is legal for the bank to place any type where the requirements are met, although bank policy may instruct that the type of hold placed be the one that holds the most funds the longest that can be applied legally.
As of February 27, 2010, there is only one check processing region for the entire United States. Therefore, all checks are now local.<ref>[http://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/press/bcreg/20091231a.htm Amendments to Appendix A of Regulation CC.] (Federal Reserve website) "... the amendments are effective February 27, 2010. At that time, there will only be a single check-processing region for purposes of Regulation CC and there will no longer be any checks that are nonlocal."</ref><ref>[http://www.frbservices.org/communications/check_restructuring.html Federal Reserve Banks' Check Restructuring Resource Center]. Top-level page pointing to more detailed pages.</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Hold type ! Necessary requirements ! Local availability |- | '''Statutory''' | No other hold applies, can be placed almost anytime. | $200 first business day following deposit, $600 second business day following deposit, remainder third business day
|- | '''Large deposit''' | Aggregate total of checks deposited into one account on one business day is greater than $5,000.00. | $200 first business day following deposit,$600 second business day following deposit, $4,800 third business day following deposit, remainder seventh business day
|- | '''New account''' | The account being deposited into has been open for less than 30 days. | Ninth business day
|- | '''Exception''' | {| class="wikitable" |- | Account has been overdrawn for six or more business days of the previous six months. ('''NSF ("non-sufficient funds") hold''') |- | Account has been overdrawn for two or more business days in excess of $5,000 in the previous six months. ('''NSF hold''') |- | The depository bank has reason to doubt the check is good. (The paying bank indicates the check will not [[clearing (finance)|clear]], is suspected to be fraudulent, or is either postdated or staledated.) |- | The item being deposited is a legal copy of an item previously returned for NSF (an IRD). |- | Item is accepted for deposit during a power outage or computer failure (''extremely rare''). |} | Seventh business day
|}
'''Regarding insurance checks''', if the insurance check is drawn on an in-state bank funds will be available on the 5th business day; if the insurance check is drawn on an out-of-state bank funds will be available on the 7th business day.
There are a few exceptions to these guidelines that are important to note. If an account owner is depositing into an account that does not qualify for the exception hold but also owns another account that does qualify, then the Exception NSF Hold can be placed. In the same manner, if an account owner is depositing into an account that has been open for less than 30 days but owns another account that has been open greater than 30 days, the New Account Hold cannot be legally placed.
There are certain items that present less risk to financial institutions and thus are subject to expedited availability under the stipulations of Regulation CC. The following items must have the first $5000 available for the Statutory, Large Deposit and New Account Hold by the first business day following the deposit:
*Cashier's checks, certified checks, or teller's checks<nowiki>*</nowiki>; *Postal money orders; *U.S. Treasury checks; *Checks drawn on a Federal Reserve Bank or Federal Home Loan Bank; *Any check issued by a state, city, county, or other municipality; *Any check drawn from another account at the depository institution.
For each of these items, the item must be presented for deposit into the payee's account for it to receive expedited fund availability; when one of these checks is presented for deposit into a third party account, it loses its preferential treatment. Also, the bank may require use of a special deposit slip or envelope for next-day availability of cashier's checks, certified checks, teller's checks, or state & local government checks; if it does so, it must notify customers and tell them how to obtain the special slip or envelope.
<nowiki>*</nowiki>''Regulation CC defines a "cashier's check" as a check that is issued by a bank, drawn on that same bank, is a direct liability of the bank, and signed by one or more officers of that bank. Though the term "teller's check" is commonly used only by Federal credit unions, under Regulation CC '''any''' check "drawn by the bank, and drawn on another bank or payable through or at a bank" is a "teller's check" if issued "for remittance purposes". "Official Checks" or "Bank Checks" may not qualify as "cashier's checks" under Regulation CC, but they usually qualify for next-day availability as "teller's checks".''
== Payment of interest == According to the regulation, interest-bearing accounts shall receive earnings from funds from the time they are collected by the depository institution, regardless of hold lengths.
== Enforcement == Under the act, enforcement is divided by the type of institution, respective to each type's mandated oversight authority: *For national banks, and federal branches and agencies of foreign banks, the act is enforced by the [[Office of the Comptroller of the Currency]]; *For members of the [[Federal Reserve System]] who are not national banks, and for offices, branches, and agencies of foreign banks located in the United States (who are not federal branches and agencies of foreign banks), the provisions are enforced by the [[Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve]]; *In the case of banks insured by the [[Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation]] who are not members of the Federal Reserve System, and insured state branches of foreign banks, enforcement falls to the Board of Directors of the [[Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation]] (FDIC); *The Director of the [[Office of Thrift Supervision]] is responsible for enforcing the provisions of the act in the case of savings associations whose deposits are insured by the FDIC; *Federal credit unions or [[credit union]]s insured by the [[National Credit Union Share Insurance Fund]] are subject to enforcement of the act by the [[National Credit Union Administration Board]].
Awards for damages are limited under the regulation, including not more than $1000 in addition to actual damages for individual actions, and not more than the lesser of $500,000 or 1% of the net worth of the bank, in addition to actual damages, for class actions.
==Related legislation== On June 9, 2014, the [[United States House of Representatives]] passed {{USBill|113|HR|1679}} ''To amend the Expedited Funds Availability Act to clarify the application of that Act to American Samoa and the Northern Mariana Islands.''<ref name=1679actions>{{cite web|title=H.R. 1679 - Actions|url=http://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/1679/actions|publisher=United States Congress|accessdate=10 June 2014}}</ref> The bill, if it were to become law, would extend "by two business days, for [[American Samoa]], any time periods established for large or redeposited check, repeated overdraft, reasonable cause, or other emergency exceptions to the 30-day funds availability requirements for deposits in an depository institution account by a new depositor."<ref name=1679sum>{{cite web|title=H.R. 1679 - Summary|url=http://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/1679|publisher=United States Congress|accessdate=10 June 2014}}</ref> It would also apply "this two-day extension to any deposit in an account at a depository institution located in American Samoa by a check drawn on an originating depository institution which is not located in the same state as the receiving depository institution."<ref name="1679sum"/>

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox company | name = Huntingdon Life Sciences | logo = File:Huntingdon-logo-for-wiki.jpg | caption = Huntingdon Life Sciences' official logo | type = | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = | founder = | defunct = | location_city = | location_country = | location = | locations = United Kingdom, United States, Japan | area_served = Global | key_people = [[Brian Cass]], Managing Director | industry = Contract research organisation for the pharmaceutical, biopharmaceutical, crop protection, chemical, veterinary and food industries. | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = >1,600 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{url|http://www.huntingdon.com/|Huntingdon Life Sciences}} | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Huntingdon Life Sciences''' ('''HLS''') is a [[contract research organisation]] (CRO) founded in 1951 in Cambridgeshire, England. It has two laboratories in the United Kingdom and one in the United States. With over 1600 staff, it is now the largest non-clinical CRO in Europe.<ref name="Agrow Awards">{{cite web|url=http://www.agrow.com/multimedia/archive/00068/DS239_68757a.pdf |title=AGROW'S 30 LEADING CONTRACT RESEARCH ORGANISATIONS |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref> In September 2015, Huntingdon Life Sciences, [[Harlan (company)|Harlan Laboratories]], GFA, NDA Analytics and LSR associates merged into [[Envigo]].
In 2009, HLS was bought outright and is now in private ownership. Prior to this, the latest Annual Report (2008) showed that the company had revenues of $US242.4m and an Operating Profit of 14.8%.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aQbXuxCXzquQ | work=Bloomberg | title=LSR Announces Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2008 Results}}</ref>
Although HLS is the third-largest non-clinical CRO in the world, it is probably better known to the general public as the target of a high-profile [[animal rights]] campaign. The campaign, in the main, has been orchestrated by the animal rights group [[Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty]] (SHAC).<ref name="SHAC website">{{cite web|url=http://www.shac.net |title=SHAC website |publisher=Shac.net |date= |accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref>
==Locations== HLS has two facilities in the UK ([[Huntingdon]], Cambridgeshire and Eye, Suffolk), one in the USA ([[East Millstone, New Jersey]]) and an office in Japan (Tokyo).
==History== Huntingdon Life Sciences was founded in the UK in 1951 as Nutrition Research Co. Ltd., a commercial organisation that initially focused on [[nutrition]], [[veterinary]], and [[biochemical]] research. The original facilities were split over two locations; the main offices were within Cromwell House in the town of Huntingdon, Cambs, UK; and the main laboratories were at the Hartford Field Station (just over a mile away). It then became involved with [[pharmaceuticals]], [[food additives]], and industrial and consumer chemicals. In 1959 it changed its name to Nutritional Research Unit Ltd. The company benefited in the early 1960s from increased government regulatory testing requirements, especially in the pharmaceutical industry. In 1964 it was acquired by the U.S. medical supply firm of Becton Dickinson.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/history2/92/Huntingdon-Life-Sciences-Group-plc.html |title=HLS Group |publisher=Reference for Business |date= |accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref>
In April 1983, [[Becton Dickinson]] created Huntingdon Research Centre PLC. It then offered four million [[American depositary receipt]]s (ADRs) for sale at $15 each, representing the company's entire interest in Huntingdon. In 1985, as it began to expand its operations, the company changed its name to Huntingdon International Holdings plc. In that year it established Huntingdon Analytical Services Inc. to conduct business in the United States.
To augment its CRO business, Huntingdon acquired Minnesota's Twin City Testing Laboratory Inc. and affiliated companies in 1985, followed by the acquisition of Nebraska Testing Corporation in 1986; Travis Laboratories and Kansas City Test Laboratory Inc. in 1989; and Southwestern Laboratories, Inc. in 1990. Huntingdon also diversified its operations, primarily in the United States, becoming involved in engineering and environmental services.
In 1987, HLS purchased Northern Engineering and Testing, Inc., and then in 1988 bought Empire Soils Investigations Inc., Chen Associates Inc., and Asteco Inc. In 1988 HLS was floated on the [[London Stock Exchange]] and in 1989 obtained a listing on the [[New York Stock Exchange]]. In 1990 Huntingdon acquired the St. Louis branch of Envirodyne Engineers Inc. and Whiteley Holdings Ltd. And in 1991 it acquired Austin Research Engineers, Inc., followed by Travers Morgan Ltd.
By the early 1990s, Huntingdon was organised into three business groups: the Life Sciences Group, the Engineering/Environmental Group, and the Travers Morgan Group, which offered engineering and environmental consulting services outside of the United States. However, only the Life Sciences Group showed long-term promise. Travers Morgan was allowed to lapse into insolvency, control passed into other hands, and Huntingdon wrote off the investment. In 1995 the engineering and environmental businesses were sold to Maxim Engineers Inc. of Dallas, Texas.
To bolster its CRO business and reinforce its U.S. presence, Huntingdon in 1995 acquired the toxicology business of Applied Biosciences International for $32.5 million in cash, plus the Leicester Clinical Research Centre. The deal not only included a U.S. laboratory located near [[Princeton, New Jersey]], it brought with it two British facilities as well. In 1997 Huntingdon International Holdings changed its name to Huntingdon Life Sciences Group. The U.K. subsidiary, Huntingdon Research Centre, changed its name to Huntingdon Life Sciences Ltd., while the U.S. business operated as Huntingdon Life Sciences Inc.
In 2002, HLS moved its financial centre to the [[United States]] and incorporated in [[Maryland]] as Life Sciences Research.
In 2009, HLS was bought outright and once again is in private ownership.<ref>BusinessWire: Life Sciences Research, Inc. Announces Consummation of Going Private Transaction [http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20091124006124/en/Life-Sciences-Research-Announces-Consummation-Private-Transaction]</ref>
==Core industries== HLS provides [[Contract Research Organisation]] services in pre-clinical and non-clinical biological safety evaluation research. As with other major CROs operating in this business area, its major business is serving the pharmaceutical industry. However, more than a third of its business comes from non-pharmaceutical sources, the most important of which is the [[crop protection]] industry which accounts for around 60% of their non-pharmaceutical business.<ref name="Agrow Awards"/>
==Staff numbers== The latest available public figures from 2008 show that HLS employs more than 1600 staff across all of its facilities. They break down as:<ref>HLS Annual Report 2008</ref> {| class="wikitable" |- ! !! 2008 !! 2007 |- | '''UK''' || 1303 || 1313 |- | '''US''' || 333 || 309 |- | '''Japan''' || 12 || 12 |- | '''Total''' || 1648 || 1634 |}
==Trade bodies and associations== * [[Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry]] (ABPI) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abpi.org.uk/about-us/membership/Pages/research-affiliate-list.aspx |title=Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry |publisher=Abpi.org.uk |date= |accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref> * Bioindustry Association (BIA) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bioindustry.org/membership/member-directory/?alpha=H |title=Bioindustry Association |publisher=Bioindustry.org |date= |accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref> * [[Association for Assessment and Accreditation of Laboratory Animal Care]] (AAALAC) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aaalac.org/accreditedorgs/aaalacprgms.cfm |title=Association for Assessment and Accreditation of Laboratory Animal Care |publisher=Aaalac.org |date= |accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref> * Society of Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry (SETAC) * [[Fund for the Replacement of Animals in Medical Experiments]] (FRAME) <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.frame.org.uk/page.php?pg_id=44 |title=Fund for the Replacement of Animals in Medical Experiments |publisher=Frame.org.uk |date= |accessdate=3 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415104620/http://www.frame.org.uk/page.php?pg_id=44 |archivedate=15 April 2012 |df= }}</ref> * Institute of Animal Technology (IAT) * [[Understanding Animal Research]] (UAR) <ref>[http://www.understandinganimalresearch.org.uk/about_us/member_organisations Understanding Animal Research] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110909055105/http://www.understandinganimalresearch.org.uk/about_us/member_organisations |date=9 September 2011 }}</ref>
==Honours and awards== *Agrow Awards Best Supporting Role 2007.{{cn|date=August 2018}} *Queens Award for Export Achievement 1982.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rIK0qp_hyccC&pg=PA57&lpg=PA57&dq=huntingdon+life+sciences+Queens+Awards+for+Export&source=bl&ots=hg6-zbQT7R&sig=dqH6txT5TWvWxUElqL8vD3iTsgI&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Kb4NT-PmPIudOu608bkH&sqi=2&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=huntingdon%20life%20sciences%20Queens%20Awards%20for%20Export&f=false |title=Queens Award for Export Achievement |publisher=Books.google.co.uk |date=17 May 1984 |accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref>
==Use of animals== HLS uses animals in the biomedical research it conducts for its customers. The most recent numbers released state that in the UK around 60,000 animals are used annually.<ref>[http://www.huntingdon.com/ethics/animals-used-in-research.html Huntingdon Life Sciences website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111227223520/http://www.huntingdon.com/ethics/animals-used-in-research.html |date=27 December 2011 }}</ref> This number is broken down by species:
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- !style="width: 100px;"| Animal !style="width: 100px;"| Usage |- | [[Mouse]] | 19.25% |- | [[Fish]] | 3.45% |- | [[Rat]] | 71.05% |- | [[Bird]] | 0.92% |- | Other [[mammals]] | 5.31% |}
==Controversy== Huntingdon is criticised by [[animal rights]] and [[animal welfare]] groups for using animals in research, for instances of [[animal abuse]] and for the wide range of substances it tests on animals, particularly non-medical products. It is claimed by SHAC that 500 animals died every day at HLS (182,500 a year),<ref name="SHAC website 2">{{cite web|url=http://www.shac.net/news/2011/august/26-27.html |title=>> Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty |publisher=SHAC |date= |accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref> a figure at odds with HLS' published numbers.
Huntingdon's labs were infiltrated by [[undercover]] animal rights [[activists]] in 1997 in the UK and in 1998 in the US.
In 1997, film secretly recorded inside HLS in the UK by [[BUAV]] and subsequently broadcast on [[Channel 4]] television as "It's a Dog's Life", showed serious breaches of animal-protection laws, including a [[beagle]] puppy being held up by the scruff of the neck and repeatedly punched in the face, and animals being taunted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smallworldtv.co.uk/public/main.cfm?m1=c_75&m2=c_2&m3=c_54&m4=e_0 |title=Small World TV |publisher=Small World TV |date= |accessdate=3 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308224555/http://www.smallworldtv.co.uk/public/main.cfm?m1=c_75&m2=c_2&m3=c_54&m4=e_0 |archivedate=8 March 2012 |df= }}</ref>
The laboratory technicians responsible were suspended from HLS the day after the broadcast. All three were later dismissed.<ref name="CassTelegraph">[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/politics/lawandorder/4276376/The-men-who-stood-up-to-animal-rights-militants.html The men who stood up to animal rights' militants], ''The Daily Telegraph'', 17 January 2009</ref> Two of the men seen hitting and shaking dogs were found guilty under the Animals Act of 1911 of "cruelly terrifying dogs." It was the first time laboratory technicians had been prosecuted for animal cruelty in the UK. HLS admitted that the technicians' behaviour was deplorable and a new management team was introduced the following year which, according to ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', "introduced greater openness and new training methods."<ref name="CassTelegraph"/>
In 1998, an undercover investigator for [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals]] (PETA) used a camera hidden in her glasses to make 50 hours of videotape of the HLS laboratories in Princeton, New Jersey. She also made four 90-minute audiotapes, photocopied 8,000 company documents, and copied the company's client list. According to PETA some of the film she shot showed a monkey being dissected while still alive and conscious. The president of HLS in New Jersey, [[Alan Staple]], said the monkey was alive but sedated during the dissection.<ref name="Kolata">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/24/science/tough-tactics-in-one-battle-over-animals-in-the-lab.html|title=Tough Tactics In One Battle Over Animals In the Lab|last=Kolata|first=Gina|date=24 March 1998|work=The New York Times|access-date=1 December 2017|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
HLS obtained a "gagging order" in the US that prevents PETA from publicising or talking about any of the information that they discovered. The order also prevented PETA from communicating with the American Department of Agriculture, which had been going to investigate the evidence.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2465/is_2_31/ai_71634854/ |title=Seeing Is Believing - cruelty to dogs at Huntingdon Life Sciences, The Ecologist,March, 2001. |publisher=Findarticles.com |date= |accessdate=3 October 2012}}</ref>
===Protests and intimidation=== The [[Stop Huntingdon Animal Cruelty]] (SHAC) campaign is based in the UK and US, and has aimed to close the company down since 1999. According to its website, the campaign's methods are restricted to non-violent [[direct action]], as well as [[lobbying]] and demonstrations. It targets not only HLS itself, but any company, institution, or person allegedly doing business with the laboratory, whether as clients, suppliers, or even disposal and cleaning services, and the employees of those companies.
Despite its stated non-violent position, SHAC members have been convicted of crimes of violence against HLS employees. On 25 October 2010 five SHAC members received prison sentences for threatening HLS staff. SHAC has also been accused of encouraging [[arson]] and violent assault. An HLS director was assaulted in front of his child.<ref name=Piercy125>Piercy, Nigel. ''Market-Led Strategic Change: A Guide to Transforming the Process of Going to Market''. Butterworth-Heinemann 2002, p. 125.</ref> HLS managing director [[Brian Cass]] was sent a mousetrap primed with razor blades,<ref name=Piercy125/> and in February 2001 was attacked by three men armed with pickaxe handles and CS gas.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1494924.stm Jail for lab boss attacker], BBC News, 16 August 2001</ref> Another businessman with links to HLS was attacked and knocked unconscious adjacent to a barn his assailants had set alight.<ref name="CassTelegraph"/>
Both SHAC and [[Animal Liberation Front]] activists have engaged in [[harassment]] and [[intimidation]], including issuing hoax bomb threats and death threats.<ref>[http://news.scotsman.com/opinion.cfm?id=288432003 Counting the cost of fear], Scotland on Sunday, 9 March 2003.</ref> ''The Daily Mail'' cites as an example the sending of 500 letters to the neighbours of a company manager who did business with HLS; the letter contained an unsupported allegation that the man was a paedophile, with police having to inform all 500 households that the allegations were false.<ref>[http://lists.envirolink.org/pipermail/ar-news/Week-of-Mon-20031013/008215.html "The Animals of Hatred"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060629082805/http://lists.envirolink.org/pipermail/ar-news/Week-of-Mon-20031013/008215.html |date=29 June 2006 }}, ''Daily Mail'', 15 October 2003.</ref>
In 2008 seven of SHAC's senior members were described by prosecutors as "some of the key figures in the Animal Liberation Front" and found guilty of conspiracy to blackmail HLS.<ref name="TimesYeoman">Fran Yeoman [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article5391798.ece "Extremists face long jail sentences after blackmail conviction"], ''The Times'', 24 December 2008</ref>
===Effect of campaign=== The campaign against HLS led to its share price crashing, the [[Royal Bank of Scotland]] closing its bank account, and the British government arranging for the [[Bank of England]] to give them an account.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} In 2000, HLS was dropped from the [[New York Stock Exchange]] because of its [[market capitalization]] had fallen below NYSE limits.<ref name=Potter>Potter, Will. [http://www.counterpunch.org/potter05042006.html "Green is the New Red"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070408094959/http://counterpunch.org/potter05042006.html |date=8 April 2007 }}, ''Counterpunch'', 4 May 2006.</ref>
===Government response=== {{Expand section|reason= The government of the day responded to the 1997 investigative work, and additional responses were made before 2006|date=August 2012}} From 2006, ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' reports, the British Government took the decision to tackle "the problem of animal rights extremism."<ref name="CassTelegraph"/> On 1 May 2007, a police campaign called ''Operation Achilles'' was enacted against SHAC, a series of raids involving 700 police officers in England, Amsterdam, and Belgium.<ref name=spiegel>[http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/0,1518,517875-2,00.html "Britain's other war on terror"], Spiegel online, 19 November 2007</ref> In total, 32 people linked to the group were arrested,<ref>[http://www.netcu.org.uk/media/article.jsp?id=249 "Animal rights extremism – police arrest 32 people"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927074535/http://www.netcu.org.uk/media/article.jsp?id=249 |date=27 September 2007 }}, National Extremism Tactical Coordination Unit press release, 1 May 2007.</ref> and seven leading members of SHAC, including [[Greg Avery]], were found guilty of blackmail.<ref>[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/92cf1796-93d2-11dd-b277-0000779fd18c.html "Activists in live testing trial deny blackmail"], ''[[Financial Times]]'' 6 October 2008.</ref> Police estimated in 2007 that, as a consequence of the operation, "up to three quarters of the most violent activists" were jailed. ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' writes that the number of attacks on HLS and their business declined drastically but "the movement is by no means dead."<ref name=spiegel/>

{{nihongo|'''Masaki Inayoshi'''|稲吉 正樹|Inayoshi Masaki}} is the owner and founder<ref name="jtimes-sponsor">{{Citation | last =Takahara | first =Kanako | title =G.communication announced as sponsor for Nova | newspaper =Japan Times | date =2007-11-08 | url = http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nb20071108a2.html}}</ref> of [[G.Communication]], a [[Japan]]ese [[kabushiki kaisha]] based in [[Nagoya, Japan]]. The company is an operator of [[restaurant chain]]s, ''[[juku]]'' (cram schools), and ''[[eikaiwa]]'' (language schools).<ref name="jtimes-nova">{{Citation | title =G.communication set to reopen Nova school in Nagoya | newspaper =Japan Times | date =2007-11-12 | url = http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20071112a3.html}}</ref>
==Early life== Born in [[Gamagori]], [[Aichi Prefecture]], Inayoshi started working as a local city official. In 1994 Inayoshi first opened a private cram school called "[[wiktionary:ganbaru|Ganbaru]] Gakuen".,<ref name="jtimes-sponsor" /> which later became G.Communication, and quit the city office in 1995 to focus on his business.
==G.Communication== In November 2007, G.Communication took over [[Nova (eikaiwa)|Nova]] after it filed for bankruptcy in November 2007.<ref name="jtimes-nova" /> Following the April 2010 bankruptcy of [[GEOS (eikaiwa)|GEOS]], G.Communication took over 230 schools owned by the company.<ref>[http://www.asahi.com/national/update/0421/TKY201004210222.html 英会話学校のジオスが破産申請 負債７５億円] Asahi Shimbun, April 21, 2010. Retrieved April 21, 2010.</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/business/T100421005821.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20100426073909/http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/business/T100421005821.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=26 April 2010 |title=Geos English school files for bankruptcy |date=2010-04-22 |publisher=Yomiuri |accessdate=22 April 2010 |df= }} </ref> Another round of closures on October 30, 2010 affected all GEOS schools on [[Kyushu]] and most on [[Shikoku]]. GEOS is again being downsized as it and Nova are personally reclaimed from G.Education by Inayoshi Capital. Per agreement, schools in [[Ito-Yokado]] supermarkets will stay open a few months longer.{{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}
On G.Communication's website,<ref>http://www.g-com.jp/</ref> Inayoshi comments on his business philosophy, saying he runs the group as its owner because he wants to please his employees, who have invested their lives in him, and their families. To become profitable, Inayoshi said his company has to have the support of the public and franchise owners, as well as good relations with business partners and those involved with the firm.

Максим Бакиев | image =Maxim Bakijev.jpg | nationality=[[Kyrgyz people|Kyrgyz]] | order=Director of the Central Agency for Development, Investment and Innovation of the Kyrgyz Republic | term_start= October 29, 2009 | term_end= April 7, 2010 | predecessor= Post Established | successor= Post Abolished | birth_date={{Birth date and age|1977|8|27|mf=y}} | birth_place=[[Samara, Russia|Samara]], [[Russian SFSR]], [[USSR]] | dead= | death_date= | death_place= | spouse= Kenenbaeva Aizhan | party= | profession= [[Politician]] | vicepresident= | religion= [[Sunni Islam]] }} '''Maksim Kurmanbekovich Bakiyev''' ({{lang-ru|Максим Курманбекович Бакиев}}; born 27 October 1977, [[Samara, Russia|Samara]], [[RSFSR]]), is the youngest son of former president of [[Kyrgyzstan]], [[Kurmanbek Bakiyev]], from his marriage to Russian-born [[Tatyana Bakiyeva|Tatyana Petrova]]. He is a resident of the UK having been granted political asylum.https://www.hickmanandrose.co.uk/site/about/press-releases/details/bakiev-secures-interpol-victory ==Biography== ===Early life=== Maksim Bakiyev has a legal background, having graduated from the joint [[Kyrgyz-Russian Slavic University]]. As a student, Maksim worked in a consulting firm, specialized in investment into emerging markets in Central Asia and the Middle East. In March 2010 Maksim was widely believed to be the richest man in Kyrgyzstan.[http://rt.com/Politics/2010-06-15/maksim-bakiyev-most-wanted.html Maksim Bakiyev – most wanted in Kyrgyzstan] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100617024712/http://rt.com/Politics/2010-06-15/maksim-bakiyev-most-wanted.html |date=June 17, 2010 }} ===Career=== Maksim was appointed the head of the Central Agency for Development in October 2009. Since the 2010 overthrow he has been charged with embezzlement and abuse of power by the interim government of Kyrgyzstan. It is suspected that he transferred about $35 million of a $300 million loan from Russia into his private bank accounts.{{cite web|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20100416/158613170.html |title=Bakiyev's son suspected of Russian loan embezzlement |publisher=En.rian.ru |date=2010-04-16 |accessdate=2014-02-11}} Prosecutors also alleged that his companies owed almost $80 million in taxes on aviation fuel sales.[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100615/ap_on_re_as/as_kyrgyzstan UN says violence in Kyrgyzstan was orchestrated] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100617212043/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20100615/ap_on_re_as/as_kyrgyzstan |date=June 17, 2010 }} A civil fraud claim regarding this was brought in the UK High Court and was withdrawn by two Kygrz Republic agencies in October 2016, and he has no charges for fraud against him.https://www.hickmanandrose.co.uk/site/about/press-releases/details/kyrgyz-withdraws-20-million-fraud-claim-against-bakiev During the [[2010 Kyrgyzstan uprising|2010 uprising]] in Kyrgyzstan, Maxim Bakiyev was headed to the US for a series of meetings in Washington.{{cite web|last=Rothkopf |first=David |url=http://blog.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2010/04/19/where_in_the_world_is_maksim_bakiyev |title=Where in the world is Maksim Bakiyev? |publisher=Blog.foreignpolicy.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-11}} However, he never showed up. In May [[Interpol]] posted Maxim Bakiyev as wanted on its website. In 2016, following the successful dismissal of all fraud and criminal charges against Maxim Bakiev, Interpol withdrew its red notice against Mr Bakiev.https://www.hickmanandrose.co.uk/site/about/press-releases/details/bakiev-secures-interpol-victory ==Arrest and asylum== On June 13, 2010, Maksim was arrested in the UK when he landed at [[Farnborough Airport]] in Hampshire in a privately hired jet.https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/met-arrests-son-of-ousted-kyrgyz-leader-8210436.html He sought asylum there but the interim government demanded his extradition at the time.https://www.hickmanandrose.co.uk/site/about/press-releases/details/bakiev-secures-interpol-victory A senior Kyrgyz official warned that the interim government would consider shutting down the U.S. [[Transit Center at Manas|Manas airbase]] if Britain refuses to hand him over.{{cite web|author=Miriam Elder in Moscow |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jun/17/kyrgyzstan-us-airbase-warning |title=Kyrgyzstan threatens to shut US base unless ex-president's son is extradited |publisher=Guardian |date= |accessdate=2014-02-11}} However, this was later denounced by president of Kyrgyzstan, [[Roza Otunbayeva]]. On October 12, 2012, Bakiyev was arrested in London by UK extradition officers on the request of U.S. authorities, who want to question him for alleged involvement in fraud. In a statement, the Kyrgyz presidency declared: "''Because of the absence of an extradition agreement between the Kyrgyz Republic and Great Britain, the British side is now considering the issue of extraditing Maxim Bakiyev to the United States.''"{{cite news|title=Ex Kyrgyz President's Son Arrested in London|url=http://www.satrapia.com/news/article/ex-kyrgyz-presidents-son-arrested-in-london/|newspaper=The Gazette of Central Asia|date=13 October 2012|publisher=Satrapia}} On March 27, 2013, a Kyrgyz court sentenced Bakiyev in absentia to 25 years in prison for corruption.{{cite news|title=Former Kyrgyz President's Son Sentenced in Absentia to 25 years Jail|url=http://www.satrapia.com/news/article/former-kyrgyz-presidents-son-sentenced-in-absentia-to-25-years-jail/|newspaper=The Gazette of Central Asia|date=28 March 2013|publisher=Satrapia}} In May 2013, a US criminal securities fraud case against him was dismissed.https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2013-05-09/u-s-case-ends against-ex-kygryz-leader-bakiyev-s-son In 2016 a personal injury claim against Maxim Bakiev was brought by British businessman Mr Sean Daley, alleging that his shooting and attempted murder in Bishkek had been organized and arranged by Mr Bakiev, was dismissed at the High Court of Justice in London as not "credible", "unsatisfactory" and "wholly implausible". Evidence submitted was stated by Mr Justice Supperstone to give "rise to real concern that it was made in collaboration with Mr Ismailov (the Kyrgyz prosecutor)for the purpose of ensuring the conviction of Mr Bakiev.https://www.hickmanandrose.co.uk/site/about/press-releases/details/high-court-dismisses-personal-injury-claim-against-maksim ==2010 South Kyrgyzstan unrest== In May 2010, an audio recording{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6KB8GAnNM78&feature=channel |title=Phone conversation between Maksim and Janybek Bakiyev |publisher=Youtube |date=2012-01-29 |accessdate=2014-02-11}} was posted anonymously on YouTube with a caption identifying the voices as those of Maxim and his uncle [[Janish Bakiyev]]. The men were discussing plans to arm groups to spread chaos across the south of Kyrgyzstan, sometime in June. Both men have denied the authenticity of the tape and Bakiyev has repeatedly said he has no involvement in the violence.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia/2010/06/20106164631604263.html |title=Kyrgyz violence level 'alarming' |publisher=English.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2014-02-11}} There is no evidence to incriminate the Bakievs in the June events.https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Full_Report_490.pdf Kyrgyz deputy Prime Minister [[Almazbek Atambayev]], claims that the [[2010 South Kyrgyzstan riots|2010 inter-ethnic riots in south Kyrgyzstan]] were paid for with $10 million from Bakiyev's pocket.{{cite web|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20100615/159430286.html |title=Kyrgyzstan to seek extradition of ex-president's son over riots |publisher=En.rian.ru |date=2010-06-15 |accessdate=2014-02-11}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bakijev, Maxim}} [[Category:1977 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Kyrgyzstani businesspeople]] [[Category:Kyrgyzstani politicians]] [[Category:Kyrgyzstani people of Russian descent]] [[Category:People from Samara, Russia]] [[Category:Kyrgyz Revolution of 2010]]

'''Medical logistics''' is the [[logistics]] of pharmaceuticals, medical and surgical supplies, medical devices and equipment, and other products needed to support doctors, nurses, and other health and dental care providers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tpub.com/content/armymedical/MD0029/|title=Introduction to Medical Logistics Management|date=2010|publisher=U.S. ARMY MEDICAL DEPARTMENT CENTER AND SCHOOL|accessdate=2010-01-07}}</ref> Because its final customers are responsible for the lives and health of their patients, medical logistics is unique in that it seeks to optimize [[effectiveness]] rather than [[Economic efficiency|efficiency]]. Medical logistics functions comprise an important part of the health care system: after staff costs, medical supplies are the single most expensive component of health care. To drive costs out of the health-care sector, medical logistics providers are adopting supply chain management theories.
This organizational chart is as follows and separated into three key areas.
# [[Medical Materiel]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tpub.com/content/armymedical/MD0029/MD00290018.htm|title=Materiel Branch|date=2010|publisher=U.S. ARMY MEDICAL DEPARTMENT CENTER AND SCHOOL|accessdate=2010-01-07}}</ref> # Biomedical Engineering ([[BMET]]) or [[Clinical Engineering]] # Facilities Management.
These areas are managed by a qualified Director of Logistics. The Director of Logistcs educational background holds some type of accredited graduate degree ([[MBA]] or [[Master of Science|M.S.]])

'''Michael Tojner''' is an Austrian industrial entrepreneur, author, and professor at the [[Vienna University of Economics and Business]].
== Early life and education ==
Tojner grew up in the city of [[Haag]], [[Lower Austria]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Lehner |first=Josef |date=2014-10-29 |title=Alpine nutzt den Ruf einer Weltmarke |url=http://www.nachrichten.at/nachrichten/wirtschaft/wirtschaftsraumooe/Alpine-nutzt-den-Ruf-einer-Weltmarke;art467,1529416|work=Oberösterreichische Nachrichten |location= |archive-url= |archive-date=}}</ref> Tojner went to the Bundesrealgymnasium Amstetten until 1984.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://absolventenverein.ostarrichi-gymnasium.at/content/news.html |title=Ein Abend für Absolventen, Lehrer und Freunde der Schule |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2014-10-06 |website= |publisher=Absolventenverein des Amstettner Ostarrichi-Gymnasiums|quote=}}</ref> While attending the [[Vienna University of Economics and Business]] Tojner wrote a dissertation about Venture Capital in 1990 which has been published by the „[[Ludwig Boltzmann Institut für Menschenrechte|Ludwig Boltzmann Institut]]“.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://data.onb.ac.at/rec/AC00167506 |title=Eine betriebswirtschaftliche und rechtliche Analyse von Venture Capital |publisher= |date=1990}}</ref>
In 1996 Tojner presented a thesis about the juridical circumstances of privatization in Czechia and graduated Doctor juris at the [[University of Vienna]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Tojner|first=Michael |date=1996 |title=Privatisierung in Tschechien : eine Analyse des Privatisierungsansatzes unter besonderer Berücksichtigung der verfassungs- und verwaltungsrechtlichen Grundlagen |url=http://data.onb.ac.at/rec/AC01521085 |location=Wien |publisher= |page= |isbn= |author-link= }}</ref> Tojner applied lectureship at the Institute of External Trade on Holding Finance at the Vienna University of Economics and Business and has become professor in 2017.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wu.ac.at/auha/team/ad/steiner/ |title= Wirtschaftsuniversität Wien, Betriebswirtschaftslehre des Außenhandels |last= |first= |date= |website= |publisher= Vienna University of Economics and Business|quote=}}</ref>
== Career ==
Tojner co-founded [[Bwin.party digital entertainment|bwin]] and Global Equity Partners.<ref>{{cite web |title=Protector of Austrian Industry Jewels Turns Into Raid Target |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-10-22/protector-of-austrian-industry-jewels-turns-into-raid-target |website=Bloomberg}}</ref> He invested in 50 different start-up companies overall.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://diepresse.com/home/meingeld/uebergeld/3880785/Michael-Tojner_Auf-zwei-Freunde-kommen-acht-Feinde|title=Michael Tojner: "Auf zwei Freunde kommen acht Feinde" |publisher= Die Presse |date=2014-10-10 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Selfmademillionär Michael Tojner: Immer für eine Erregung gut |url=https://derstandard.at/2000089807805/Selfmademillionaer-Michael-TojnerImmer-fuer-eine-Erregung-gut |website=Der Standard}}</ref>
In 2006 he founded the industry group [[:de:Montana Tech Components|Montana Tech Components]] AG.<ref>{{cite web |title=Michael Tojner investiert mit Montana Tech in Luftfahrt-Sparte |url=https://www.trend.at/wirtschaft/michael-tojner-montana-tech-luftfahrt-sparte-10344307 |website=[[Trend (magazine)|Trend]] |language=de |date=14 September 2018}}</ref> The Montana Group contains companies such as Universal Alloy Corporation, Asta, [[:de:Alpine Metal Tech|Alpine Metal Tech]], Aluflexpack<ref>{{cite web |title=B&C-Übernahme - Tojner: Vom Eisverkäufer zum Großinvestor |url=https://www.tt.com/ticker/14949681/b-c-uebernahme-tojner-vom-eisverkaeufer-zum-grossinvestor |website=Tiroler Tageszeitung |date=26 October 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Müller |first1=Giorgio V. |title=Montana Tech Components strebt nach einer weiteren Verdoppelung von Umsatz und Gewinn |url=https://www.nzz.ch/wirtschaft/montana-tech-components-strebt-nach-einer-weiteren-verdoppelung-von-umsatz-und-gewinn-ld.1394833 |website=Neue Zürcher Zeitung |language=de-CH |date=2 July 2018}}</ref> and the [[VARTA | Varta AG]], which joined the [[Frankfurt Stock Exchange]] noted in [[Prime Standard]] during October 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zeit.de/wirtschaft/unternehmen/2017-10/batteriehersteller-varta-boersengang-aktien|title= Varta startet mit Höchstpreis an der Börse |publisher=Die Zeit |date=2017-10-19}}</ref>
As an active part of the WertInvest management Tojner takes action in the real estate business since the 1990s. Well known projects are the purchasing of the Vienna [[InterContinental Hotels Group | InterContinental]], Posthouse<ref>{{cite web|url=http://diepresse.com/home/panorama/wien/4749128/Wien_Ein-Hotel-im-alten-Postgebaeude|title= Ein Hotel im alten Postgebäude |publisher= Die Presse |date=2015-06-07}}</ref> and the Hotel Kummer in Vienna.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ots.at/presseaussendung/OTS_20150603_OTS0109/forbes-austria-finanzinvestor-tojner-plant-mit-motto-gruender-schlacher-neue-hotelprojekte|title= Forbes Austria: Finanzinvestor Tojner plant mit Motto-Gründer Schlacher neue Hotelprojekte |publisher= Forbes Austria |date=2015-06-03 }}</ref>
== Controversy ==
The project „Wohnturm“ at Vienna's “Heumarkt” has been a controversial subject in the public.<ref>{{cite journal |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=2017-10-22 |title= Das umstrittene Projekt: Die Zukunft am Heumarkt |url= |journal=Presse am Sonntag |volume= |issue= |page=10 |doi= |access-date=}}</ref> Though it has been approved by the majority of Vienna's local council on the first of June 2017<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wien.orf.at/news/stories/2846556/|title= Heumarkt-Projekt im Gemeinderat beschlossen| publisher=ORF broadcaster |date=2017-06-01 }}</ref> Tojners investment in Vienna inner city has attracted criticism<ref>{{cite web|url=https://global.handelsblatt.com/finance/mr-300-percent-844431|title= Mr. 300 Percent |publisher= Handelsblatt Global |date=2017-10-28}}</ref> by local citizens for intervening the baroque architecture and endangering the city's status as UNESCO World Heritage Site.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://metropole.at/urban-planning-vienna-unesco-status/|title= Cities bask in UNESCO world heritage status. But what happens if it conflicts with modern city planning? |publisher= Metropole Vienna |date=2017-08-30 }}</ref>
== Publications ==
* Privatisierung in Tschechien: eine Analyse des Privatisierungsansatzes unter besonderer Berücksichtigung der verfassungs- und verwaltungsrechtlichen Grundlagen (Privatization in Czechia: an analysis on the approach of privatization in consideration of constitutional and administrative foundation),Wien, Univ., Diss., 1996 * Die Volkswirtschaftliche Bedeutung des Kapitalmarktes (Economic importance of the capital market); Bankarchiv, Österreichische Bankenwissenschaftliche Gesellschaft; 2001. * Investitions- und Vermögenseffekt: Realwirtschaftliche Auswirkungen von Kapitalmarktschwankungen (Investment and asset effect: real economic effects of capital market fluctuations); Bankarchiv, Österreichische Bankenwissenschaftliche Gesellschaft; 2004. * Kapitalmarkt und Volkswirtschaft (Capital market and economics); Volkswirtschaftliche Artikelserie, 2010, {{ISBN|978-3-200-01829-7}}. * Staatsschuldenkrisen und Staatsinsolvenzen (Government debt crisis and insolvencies of states), 2012, {{ISBN|978-3-200-02584-4}}. * Beteiligungskapital und Unternehmertum, Fünf Case Studies, (Equity capital and entrepreneurship, Five case studies), 2013, {{ISBN|9783709305478}}. * Staatsquoten und Pensionssysteme (National quota and pension systems), 2015, {{ISBN|978-3-7093-0613-0}}.

{{Politics of Scotland}} The '''Minister for Business, Fair Work and Skills''' is a [[Junior minister]]ial post in the [[Scottish Government]]. As a result, the Minister does not attend[http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts1998/ukpga_19980046_en_1 Scotland Act (1998)], ''Only those appointed under Section 47 of the Scotland Act "attend" Cabinet. Junior ministers are appointed under Section 49 and may be "present".'' the [[Government of the 4th Scottish Parliament|Scottish Cabinet]]. The post was retitled in June 2018: the Minister supports the [[Cabinet Secretary for Finance, Economy and Fair Work]] and the [[Cabinet Secretary for Education and Skills]], both of whom are members of cabinet.{{cite web|url=https://beta.gov.scot/about/who-runs-government/cabinet-and-ministers/minister-business-fair-work-skills/|title=Minister for Business, Fair Work and Skills|date=2018-06-27|accessdate=2018-06-27|publisher=Scottish Government}} The Minister for Business, Fair Work and Skills has specific responsibility for: *Business, industry and manufacturing *Employment policy *Labour market strategy, the living wage, and fair work *Employability programmes *Youth employment (including implementation of the Wood Commission recommendations) *Women's employment *Bankruptcy and Accountant in Bankruptcy (Scottish government agency) *Regional economic forums *Partnership Action for Continuing Employment (PACE) *Non-advanced vocational skills *Skills Development Scotland (Scotland's national skills agency) *Consumer protection == List of office holders == The current Minister for Business, Fair Work and Skills is [[Jamie Hepburn]]. {|class="wikitable" cellpadding="6" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 0 0 0 1em; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaaaaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; " |colspan="8"| === Minister for Enterprise, Energy and Tourism === |- !colspan="2"|Name ! width=75|Portrait !Entered Office !Left Office !Party !First Minister |- |{{Scottish politics/party colours/Scottish National Party}}| |[[Jim Mather]] |[[File:Jim Mather, Minister for Enterprise, Energy and Tourism (2).jpg|75px]] |17 May 2007 |20 May 2011 |[[Scottish National Party]] |[[Alex Salmond]] |- |colspan="8"| === Minister for Business, Energy and Tourism === |- |{{Scottish politics/party colours/Scottish National Party}}| |[[Fergus Ewing]] |[[File:Fergus Ewing, Minister for Community Safety (2).jpg|75px]] |20 May 2011 |18 May 2016 |[[Scottish National Party]] |[[Alex Salmond]]
[[Nicola Sturgeon]] |- |colspan="8"| === Minister for Business, Innovation and Energy === |- |{{Scottish politics/party colours/Scottish National Party}}| |[[Paul Wheelhouse]] |[[File:PaulWheelhouseMSP20110507.JPG|75px]] |18 May 2016 |27 June 2018 |[[Scottish National Party]] |[[Nicola Sturgeon]] |- |colspan="8"| === Minister for Business, Fair Work and Skills === |- |{{Scottish politics/party colours/Scottish National Party}}| |[[Jamie Hepburn]] |[[File:JamieHepburnMSP20110511.JPG|75px]] |27 June 2018 |''Incumbent'' |[[Scottish National Party]] |[[Nicola Sturgeon]] |} ==History== From 1999 to 2007, enterprise and energy were the responsibility of the '''Minister for Enterprise and Lifelong Learning'''. The [[Second McConnell government]] from 2003 to 2007 instituted Tourism as a portfolio, combined with Culture and Sport, as the '''Minister for Tourism, Culture and Sport'''. The [[Government of the 3rd Scottish Parliament|Salmond government]], elected following the [[Scottish Parliament election, 2007]] created the junior post of '''Minister for Enterprise, Energy and Tourism''' by combining the roles. In November 2014 his post became the '''Minister for Business, Energy and Tourism''', as part of the [[first Sturgeon government]]. The post was retitled as '''Minister for Business, Innovation and Energy''' as part of the [[second Sturgeon government]], and renamed again in June 2018 to Business, Fair Work and Skills. ==See also== *[[Scottish Parliament]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.gov.scot/About/People/Ministers/Minister-Business-Innovation-Energy Minister for Business, Innovation and Energy] on Scottish Government website {{Junior Scottish Government Ministers}} {{Tourism in the United Kingdom}} [[Category:Ministerial posts of the Scottish Government|Business, Fair Work and Skills]] [[Category:Economy of Scotland]] [[Category:Business in Scotland]] {{Scotland-gov-stub}}

[[Edgar Matute]]| | industry = [[Auto racing|Motorsports]]| | products = Sporting activities| | homepage = [http://www.nascarmexico.com/ www.nascarmexico.com]| }} '''NASCAR Mexico''' is a joint-venture between [[NASCAR]] and [[Grupo CIE|OCESA]], a Mexican entertainment company, aiming to develop, manage and operate local motorsports events and oversee television distribution, sponsorship and licensing. '''Operational continuity''' refers to the ability of a system to continue working despite damages, losses or critical events. In the Human Resources and Organizational domain, including IT, it implies the need to determine the level of [[Resilience_(organizational)|resilience]] of the system, its ability to recover after an event, and build a system that resists to external and internal events or is able to recover after an event without losing its external [[performance management]] capability. Organizational Continuity is achieved only with specific corporate planning.<ref>Argenti, John (1974). Systematic Corporate Planning. Wiley.</ref> In the material domain, it determines the need to adopt redundant systems, performance monitoring systems, and can even imply the practice to cannibalize or to remove serviceable assemblies, sub-assemblies or components from a repairable or serviceable item of equipment in order to install them on another, in order to keep the external system performance active.<ref>North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Nato Standardization Agency AAP-6 - Glossary of terms and definitions, p 188.</ref> Operational continuity may be referred to single systems, single individuals, up to teams or entire complex systems such as IT infrastructures, implying the ability of an organization or system to continue to provide its mission.

'''Dr. Paul Kan Man-lok''', CBE, JP, [http://www.consulfrance-hongkong.org/spip.php?article3020 Chevalier de la Légion d'Honneur],[http://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/200907/01/P200906300316.htm Silver Bauhinia Star] is a Chinese technology engineer.
He is credited with having developed the world's first Chinese and multi-lingual wireless communication software/system in 1987 and is renowned as the "Father of Multi-lingual Messaging"{{citation needed|date=May 2017}} for pioneering the wireless communication transmission software in various languages. He has made significant contributions to the information technology industry in both Hong Kong and China over the last 39 years and is currently the Chairman of three information technology companies ([https://web.archive.org/web/20090121193526/http://championtechnology.com/ Champion Technology Holdings], [https://web.archive.org/web/20081206025000/http://www.kantone.com/ Kantone Holdings] and [http://www.digitalhongkong.com Digital Hong Kong.com]) which are listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. The total asset value of the three companies exceeds 6 billion dollars. He is also an Independent Non-executive Director of [http://www.clpgroup.com CLP Holdings Ltd.]
Paul Kan is currently Chairman of [http://www.italliance.com.hk/ Hong Kong IT Alliance]; Chairman of the [http://www.hkitic.org/ Hong Kong Information Technology Industry Council]; Chairman of Information and Communications Technology Services Advisory Committee,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hkservices.hktdc.com/advisory.asp?lang=en |title=Services Advisory Committees within the Hong Kong Trade Development Council |accessdate=2009-02-02 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080424025351/http://hkservices.hktdc.com/advisory.asp?lang=en |archivedate=April 24, 2008 |df= }}</ref> HKTDC; Chairman of ICT Working Group, the Hong Kong–United Kingdom Business Partnership; and Convener of the [http://www.hhibc.org Hungarian–Hong Kong Innovative Business Council.]
In 1990, Kan set up [http://www.abettertomorrow.net "A Better Tomorrow", a charity which has since contributed to community programs in education, arts, culture and religion.The cultural activities increased substantially over the years and in 2005, Kan set up as separate non profit organizations and registered as charities the [http://www.cwchf.org Chinese Cultural Heritage Protection Foundation] for Heritage activities and to save world relics by the [http://www.wcrpf.org World Cultural Relics Protection Foundation.]
Paul Kan was a programmer of the Hong Kong Government in the 1960s, providing software expertise to various government departments including education, transport, security, industry and trade. Over the next 17 years, he worked with various international groups as a systems analyst for computer projects, including the Swire Group for its aviation, trading and shipping systems. {{citation needed|date=February 2010}} He was ultimately promoted to be the General Manager of Asiadata Ltd, a joint venture computing services bureau of HSBC, Jardines, Barclays Bank and Cable & Wireless. In 1987, he founded the Champion Technology Group and soon launched the world's first Chinese message receiver and wireless communication system, a major milestone and a solid foundation for his subsequent and continuing pursuit in the information technology arena. The Champion Technology Group has since positioned itself in the development of wireless communications software and related applications in various environments. Products of the Group are distributed in over 50 countries. {{citation needed|date=February 2010}}
He was named<ref>[[Commander of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire|Order of the British Empire]].</ref> [http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/newsroom/latest-news/?view=News&id=1994591 CBE]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} by Queen Elizabeth II in the 2006 New Year's Honours List<ref>[[The London Gazette]] of Friday Saturday 30 December 2005 Supplement No.1.</ref> This award recognised Mr. Kan's contribution to business and high standard of management ethics in his business endeavours<ref>[http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/newsroom/latest-news/?view=News&id=1994591 Foreign and Commonwealth Office news on 12 January 2006.]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Kan was invested with the honour of Commendatore dell'Ordine della Stella della Solidarieta Italiana<ref>[[Italian orders of merit#Star of Italian Solidarity (Ordine della Stella della Solidarietà Italiana)|Italian orders of merit.]]</ref> (Comm OSSI) by the Italian Prime Minister Hon. [[Romano Prodi]] in 2006. The award is granted to recipients in recognition of their contribution to economic and cultural activities for Italy.
He was awarded [[Chevalier de la Légion d'Honneur]] by the French Government in 2007 and received it from H.E. Mrs. Anne-Marie Idrac, Secretary for Foreign Trade of France in 2009<ref>[http://www.consulfrance-hongkong.org/spip.php?article3020 Chevalier de la Légion d'Honneur.]</ref>
In December 2008, he was awarded the Knights Commander Grand Cross of the Royal Order Kingdom of Poland. Mr. Kan was appointed a High Member of the Royal Council in 2009.
In the 2009 Honours List of the Hong Kong SAR Government, Kan was awarded the [[Silver Bauhinia Star]].<ref>[http://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/200907/01/P200906300316.htm 2009 Honours List of the Hong Kong SAR Government]</ref> He was also appointed a [[Justice of the Peace|JP]] by the Hong Kong SAR Government in 2006.
Mr. Kan was appointed as Honorary Consul of the Republic of Hungary in the Hong Kong SAR and the Macau SAR in January 2011.

Leonardi''' is the Duca Family Professor of Technology Management at the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.tmp.ucsb.edu/files/leonardi/CV.Leonardi.pdf|title=Curriculum Vitae: Paul M. Leonardi|publisher=University of California, Santa Barbara|accessdate=2015-05-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518080834/http://www.tmp.ucsb.edu/files/leonardi/CV.Leonardi.pdf|archivedate=2015-05-18|df=}} He is also the Investment Group of Santa Barbara Founding Director of the Master of Technology Management Program. Leonardi moved to UCSB to found the [[Technology Management Program]] and start its [[Master of Technology Management]] and Ph.D. programs. Before joining UCSB, Leonardi was a faculty member in the School of Communication, the McCormick School of Engineering, and the Kellogg School of Management at Northwestern University. Leonardi’s research focuses on how companies can design their organizational networks and implement new technologies to more effectively create and share knowledge. He is particularly interested in how data intensive technologies, such as simulation and social media tools, enable new ways to access, store, and share information; how the new sources of information these technologies provide can change work routines and communication partners; and how shifts in employees’ work and communication alter the nature of an organization's expertise. His work on these topics cuts across the fields of [[Organization Studies]], [[Communication Studies]], and [[Information Systems]] and has been published in leading journals in these fields, such as ''[[Academy of Management Journal]]'', ''[[Academy of Management Review]]'', ''[[Journal of Communication]]'', ''[[Human Communication Research]]'', ''[[Information Systems Research]]'', ''[[MIS Quarterly]]'', and ''[[Organization Science (journal)|Organization Science]].'' He is also the author of three books ''[[Car Crashes Without Cars: Lessons About Simulation Technology and Organizational Change from Automotive Design]]'' (2012, MIT Press), ''[[Materiality and Organizing: Social Interaction in a Technological World]]''(2012, Oxford University Press), and ''[[Technology Choices: Why Occupations Differ in Their Embrace of New Technologies]]'' (2015, MIT Press). He has won awards for his research from the [[Academy of Management]],{{cite web|url=http://ocis.aomonline.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=438&Itemid=1|title=Gerardine DeSanctis Award :|publisher=Academy of Management |accessdate=2009-03-07}}{{cite web|url=http://publications.aomonline.org/newsletter/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=225|title=William H. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Piet Van Waeyenberge 071215.jpg|thumb|right|Piet Van Waeyenberge]] --> [[Baron]] '''Piet Paul August Van Waeyenberge''' (born [[Ghent]] 27 October 1938) is a [[Belgium|Belgian]] businessman. He is a son of [[Camille Van Waeyenberge]] and a brother of [[Jozef Van Waeyenberge]]. He was one of the founders, and is currently president, of business club [[De Warande (Club)|De Warande]]. He is married to Wina Proesmans and together they have 3 children.
==Biography== He graduated in 1956 from high school at the Sint-Jan Berchmanscollege in [[Brussels]] and obtained a licentate in Commercial and Financial Sciences at the [[Katholieke Universiteit Leuven]] in 1960. In 1962 he obtained a [[Master of Science]] in Agricultural Economics at the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign|University of Illinois Champaign]] ([[Urbana, Illinois|Urbana]], IL [[United States|USA]]) and in 1963 a [[Master of Business Administration]] at [[INSEAD]] ([[Fontainebleau]], [[France]]). In 1978 he followed the Advanced Management Program at the [[Harvard Business School]] ([[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]], MA. USA).
During his professional career he held several positions in companies, such as chairman of De Eik n.v, [[De Warande (Club)|De Warande]] vzw, Indufin s.a., and of Cultura Brussels. He was manager of BG & Co, director of [[Fortis (finance)|Fortis]] s.a. and Fortis Brussels s.a., [[Suez (company)|Suez Energy Services]] (independent director), Sobelder s.a., VUM Media/[[Corelio]] n.v., [[Janssen Pharmaceutica]] NV, and of [[Campina (company)|Campina Melkunie]] NV.
He is honorary chairman of the Vlaams Economisch Verbond ([[VOKA]]), member of the Supervisory Board of Campina Melkunie n.v., of Koninklijke Sphinx Gustavsberg n.v. and of De Eik Beheer b.v. ([[Nijmegen]]). In 1988, he founded [[Asphales]], later renamed as Fortales n.v. and was a director of [[Almanij]] (merged with KBC to form the [[KBC Group]]).
He is or has been chairman of ''cultural'' causes like [[Flagey Square|Maison de la Radio Flagey]] s.a. and Flagey asbl, and board member of Quartier des Arts asbl, the International [[Queen Elisabeth Music Competition]], of [[Europalia|Europalia International]] vzw, the Vlaamse Academische Stichting vzw, and of the [[Francqui Foundation]] (Public Benefit Foundation).
He has been honored as a ''Commandeur in de Orde van Oranje-Nassau'' (Dutch) and ''Officier in de Leopoldsorde'' (Belgian).
